Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Carbon Fiber Composites for Next-Gen Wind Turbines
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will explore a novel materials processing technology that progresses the state-of-the-art of carbon fiber composites while leveraging mature and cost-efficient manufacturing methods. The processing technology of interest produces a material that approaches the isotropic properties of high-performance metal alloys while retaining the light-weight and stiffness of carbon fiber composites. Components that are fabricated from this new composite will have higher impact strength and reduced susceptibility to delamination, compared to commercially-available carbon fiber composites. The broader impact of this project includes providing engineers with a new tool to implement previously unfeasible designs that drastically improve performance while reducing energy consumption and material waste. The rapid adoption of carbon fiber composites in the wind energy, aerospace, and defense industries provides an opportunity for the novel material developed in this project to disrupt the $25-billion global carbon fiber composite market. Effective scale-up to industrial production of the novel carbon fiber composite can revitalize the Massachusetts textiles manufacturing ecosystem and increase the competitiveness of the U.S. advanced materials manufacturing base.

The intellectual merit of this project is the continuous production of a three-dimensionally (3-D) reinforced carbon fiber prepreg that features a carbon fiber fabric reinforced with vertically aligned short carbon fibers. This novel material provides a laminated composite part with dense through-thickness and interlaminar reinforcement. Conventional carbon fiber laminates lack through-thickness reinforcement and rely on an unfilled polymer matrix to bind the layers of the laminate together, resulting in poor impact performance and frequent delamination. This project involves the roll-to-roll fabrication of 3-D reinforced carbon fiber prepregs and characterization of the produced composite material. The anticipated result of the project is the repeatable fabrication of a 3-D reinforced carbon fiber prepreg with enhanced performance compared to commercially-available prepregs. Successful completion of this project will enable further scale-up of the associated manufacturing technology and the commercial-launch of novel 3-D reinforced carbon fiber prepregs to produce stronger, lighter, and more durable composite structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the Phase I SBIR grant from the National Science Foundation, Boston Materials, Inc. (Bedford, MA) successfully developed a continuous production process to manufacture 4”-wide Z-axis milled fiber reinforced products (tradename: Supercomp™) that met the requirements of the target customers and markets. The work done during the Phase I project was used as a foundation for Boston Materials’ first commercial-scale production line and launch of Supercomp products in June 2019.

Three breakthroughs were accomplished during Phase I SBIR project. First was the creation of a roll-to-roll coating method to dispense the aqueous milled fiber slurry onto a continuous carbon fiber substrate. Next was the formulation of a Supercomp product that can match the in-plane performance of conventional composites by developing and testing over twenty unique formulations. Last was the development of a Supercomp product that can be stored and transported dry (i.e. without resin) and then processed into a composite by the end-user, via resin transfer molding or film infusion, or by an intermediate manufacturer, such as a toll prepregger.

The original process to make Supercomp materials required the milled fibers to be dispersed in a viscous liquid resin which was thinned using a solvent. The use of resins and solvents in this process complicated the scale-up to industrial production. Boston Materials had experimented with an aqueous slurry process which would be significantly easier and safer to scale-up. This water-based process was developed using a batch-scale process to produce small coupons for proof-of-concept testing. However, the water-based process had issues with stability and homogeneity of milled fibers in water. This issue was resolved during the Phase I project.

Prior to the start of the Phase I project, Boston Materials had developed a fiber alignment module that could easily be implemented into a 4”-wide roll-to-roll production process. This module had to be integrated with a slurry coating system for implementation into a roll-to-roll production process. As described above, the initial process utilized a milled fiber slurry that had viscous resins thinned with a solvent. There are turnkey solutions to dispense particle filled resins that Boston Materials was planning on leveraging for an industrial process. However, once the aqueous slurry process was selected, a new slurry dispensing system also had to be developed. Unfortunately, there were no turnkey solutions to dispense dilute slurries for a roll-to-roll coating process. Accordingly, a roll-to-roll coating method to dispense the aqueous milled fiber slurry was necessary to facilitate further scale-up. This system was successfully designed and implemented in a 12”-wide commercial production line after the Phase I project.

Boston Materials’ commercial team interviewed customers in sporting goods, industrial, aerospace and automotive sectors. These customers made it clear that their manufacturing process would strongly benefit from Z-axis reinforcement that Supercomp products provide. Additionally, these customers also required that Boston Materials’ Z-axis milled fiber reinforcement cannot detract from the in-plane performance of conventional carbon fiber composites. Supercomp products will displace these conventional composite products. After the Phase I project, Boston Materials successfully demonstrated that Supercomp products can match the in-plane performance of conventional carbon fiber composites.

As the market discovery process continued, Boston Materials realized that customers and strategic partners required a Supercomp product that did not have any resin. These customers and strategic partners often had proprietary resins that they themselves add to off-the-shelf dry carbon fiber reinforcements. With the Phase I project, Boston Materials was able to develop a Supercomp product that can be processed without any resin in order to ensure that the Supercomp technology worked with these customers as well.


Last Modified: 08/13/2019
Modified by: Michael Segal
